comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
I wonder if this is the "Orphan School" which was due to be replaced by the new Parliament House?  It looks like a Governor Macquarie era building c.1820 - Francis Greenway?

See comments etc - 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nationalarchives/8188202318/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: This building is marked as the "School of Industry" on this 1858 (how convenient!) interactive map of Sydney - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview/?pi=nla.map-rm1272-sd&rgn=... . It is where the State Library of New South Wales is now, at the SE corner of Macquarie Street and Shakespeare Place.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Also known as the "Female School of Industry (Reformatory)" in this 1870 photo (SLNSW) - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=412074 . Contemporary (1866) full description of the Female School of Industry operations - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13144241 , and building - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13142048 The charity moved in in 1826, and before then the building had been a cavalry barracks, or as marked on this 1822 interactive map, No.34 Barracks for Government Mounted Guard - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview/?pi=nla.map-f107-sd&rgn=0.... The Female School of Industry moved to new premises in Darlinghurst about 1872 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13254490 . Not yet sure when the building pictured was demolished.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Demolished shortly after June 1873 - col.5 two-thirds down - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13315204
